repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Finishes up https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/2916 and closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2912

Uses `ClassClassNode` for regular classes to get the attribute reliably at runtime (for `cdef class` it can be resolved at compile-time).

It essentially adds the line:

```
__class__ = <ClassCellNode>
```

at the start of the top-level function. This seems slightly clunky, but the advantage is that `__class__` is automatically picked up by `locals()` and is also automatically captured into the scope of any inner functions. No other approach looked like it would handle inner functions particularly easily.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3063,6 +3063,9 @@ class TransformBuiltinMethods(EnvTransform):
     """
     Replace Cython's own cython.* builtins by the corresponding tree nodes.
     """
+    def __init__(self, *args, **kwds):
+        super(TransformBuiltinMethods, self).__init__(*args, **kwds)
+        self.def_node_body_insertions = dict()

comment_data.body: Putting this into `TransformBuiltinMethods` (where "builtin" refers to `cython.*`) seems stretching it a bit. Not sure if too much…

This seems a bit convoluted. I think `len(self.env_stack[-1::-1])` just means `len(self.env_stack) - 1`, right?

And I don't think we need two loops for this. If one goes right-to-left until it stops, and the second goes left-to-right from there, then they look at the same scopes. I think we can just remember the last generator/funcdefnode that we see before the class node, going from right-to-left. And that should be doable with standard `reversed()` list iteration, not with index loops.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3174,6 +3182,67 @@ def _inject_eval(self, node, func_name):
                     node.pos, self.current_scope_node(), lenv))
         return node
 
+    def _inject_class(self, node):
+        # bare __class__ reference inside function
+        current_def_node = self.current_scope_node()
+
+        if not isinstance(current_def_node, Nodes.FuncDefNode):
+            return node
+        for n in range(len(self.env_stack[-1::-1]), 0, -1):

comment_data.body:
It's usually not good style to introduce variables conditionally that are used later on in non-trivial contexts (that one needs to reason about in order to understand that their usage is correct).

Just initialise `original_fdef_node` to None before the loop. Also, `generator_node` might be a better name for it. And finally, we prefer duck-typey attribute tests over inheritance based type tests, so use `fdef_node.is_generator` instead of `isinstance()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3174,6 +3182,67 @@ def _inject_eval(self, node, func_name):
                     node.pos, self.current_scope_node(), lenv))
         return node
 
+    def _inject_class(self, node):
+        # bare __class__ reference inside function
+        current_def_node = self.current_scope_node()
+
+        if not isinstance(current_def_node, Nodes.FuncDefNode):
+            return node
+        for n in range(len(self.env_stack[-1::-1]), 0, -1):
+            class_node, class_scope = self.env_stack[n-1]
+            if isinstance(class_node, Nodes.ClassDefNode):
+                break
+        else:
+            # failed to find a suitable class node
+            return node
+
+        is_generator = False
+        # Now go from the class_node and find the first FuncDefNode in the stack
+        for n in range(n, len(self.env_stack)):
+            fdef_node, fdef_scope = self.env_stack[n]
+            if isinstance(fdef_node, Nodes.GeneratorDefNode):
+                original_fdef_node = fdef_node

comment_data.body:
`TransformBuiltinMethods` also deals with `locals()/vars()/super()/eval()`. I realise that `__class__` isn't a *method* here but it certainly seems similar to some of those (especially `super()`) which is why it ended up here.

For now I'll update the docstring for `TransformBuiltinMethods` since it seems to have acquired this secondary, undocumented purpose.
At the moment `fdef_node.is_generator` isn't defined for `ClassDefNode` - it's only to distinguish function types, so I've reverted to the type test.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3174,6 +3182,67 @@ def _inject_eval(self, node, func_name):
                     node.pos, self.current_scope_node(), lenv))
         return node
 
+    def _inject_class(self, node):
+        # bare __class__ reference inside function

+            return node

+            if isinstance(class_node, Nodes.ClassDefNode):
+                break
+        else:
+            # failed to find a suitable class node
+            return node
+
+        is_generator = False
+        # Now go from the class_node and find the first FuncDefNode in the stack
+        for n in range(n, len(self.env_stack)):
+            fdef_node, fdef_scope = self.env_stack[n]
+            if isinstance(fdef_node, Nodes.GeneratorDefNode):
+                original_fdef_node = fdef_node

comment_data.body: Yes it can be changed into a single loop. That does seem clearer

commit.message: inject entry instead of replacing node
add has_class_reference to DefNode for injecting __class__ into locals; replace __class__ elsewhere with a NameNode
extend testing round super() and __class__ injection
ensure def_node is a python DefNode in _inject_locals
use an AttributeNode instead of a NameNode
Fixed code-style issues and Py2 tests

Add missing attribute to pxd file

for "all" tests

title: Fix behaviour of __class__ special variable
